SEARCH
Module io.jstach.ezkv.kvs
Package io.jstach.ezkv.kvs

Interface KeyValuesResource

public sealed interface KeyValuesResource
Represents a resource that contains key-value pairs to be loaded and processed. A KeyValuesResource includes a URI, optional parameters, and metadata flags that determine its behavior during loading.

Resource URIs

Out of the box, Ezkv supports the following URI schemas:

  • "classpath" - classpath resource
  • "file" - file resource
  • "system" - System properties
  • "env" - Environment variables
  • "cmd" - Command line argument pairs separated by =
  • "stdin" - Allows Unix piping of key values, often useful for passwords
  • "profile." - Will load multiple resources based on a CSV of profiles where the profile name replaces part of the URI

Resource Keys

Resources can have special keys associated with them. The most important key is the load key (KEY_LOAD), which assigns a name to the resource. The resource name is the text after the "_" + "load" + "_" which becomes the resource name and the value of the key should be a URI. The resource name must match the regex: "[a-zA-Z0-9]+". For example _load_myresource=URI would have the name "myresource".

All other keys can be specified in two ways:

  1. In-URI keys: As query parameters in the resource's URI (these keys will be removed before the resource is loaded).
  2. In-Resource keys: As additional key-value pairs within the same resource, using the resource name as part of the key (they keys will be removed from the final result).
The parameters are combined from both the "In-URI keys" and "In-Resource keys" but "In-Resource keys" take prededence on collision. One advantage that "In-URI keys" have is that they do not need the resource name as that can be deduced and order is guaranteed which is important for filters.
Resource Keys using default syntax
Resource Key(s) Resource Syntax URI Syntax Description
"load" _load_[resource] N/A Specifies a resource to load. The resource name is defined as the content following _load_. It should be alphanumeric with no spaces.
"flags" or "flag" _flags_[resource] _flags Defines flags associated with a resource. Replace [resource] with the actual resource name.
"mediaType" or "mime" _mediaType_[resource] _mediaType Specifies the media type of a resource. Replace [resource] with the actual resource name.
"param" or "parm" _param_[resource]_[name] _param_[name] Defines parameters associated with a resource. Replace [resource] with the actual resource name, and [name] with the parameter name, which should be alphanumeric with no spaces.
"filter" or "filt" _filter_[resource]_[filter] _filter_[filter] Specifies filters to apply to a resource. Replace [resource] with the actual resource name, and [filter] with the filter identifier, both of which should be alphanumeric with no spaces.

Resource Flags

As mentioned above flags are set with the "flags" key.
Resource loading flags
Flag Value Description
"NO_REQUIRE" Indicates that the resource is optional and no error should occur if it is not found. Synonym: "OPTIONAL"
"SENSITIVE" Marks the resource as containing sensitive key-value pairs, which should not be displayed or included in output such as toString.
"NO_ADD" Indicates that the key-value pairs from the resource should only be added to variables and not to the final resolved key-value set.
"NO_INTERPOLATE" Disables interpolation entirely for key-value pairs loaded from this resource.

Note: flags can be negated textual by appending NO_ / NOT_ or removing NO_ (if present) and are case insensitive

Resource Filters

As mentioned previously filters are set with the "filter" key.

Out of the box, Ezkv supports the following resource filters:

Resource Filters
Filter Description
"grep" Grep filter, similar to Unix grep, allows picking keys based on matching regex.
"sed" Sed filter, similar to Unix sed, can rename or delete key-value keys using substitution (s) or delete (d) commands.
Example usage for building a KeyValuesResource: 
var resource = KeyValuesResource.builder("classpath:/config.properties")
	.name("config")
	.flags("optional,interpolate")
	.parameter("key1", "value1")
	.sensitive(true)
	.build();
See Also:
  • KeyValuesServiceProvider
  • KeyValuesLoader.Builder.add(KeyValuesResource)
  • builder(URI)

    DEFAULT_KEY_SEP
    By default resource keys use this as separator to separate the resource key and resource name (KEY_LOAD) as well as other key properties (filter id for KEY_FILTER and parameter name for KEY_PARAM).

    FILTER_GREP
    Grep filter just like unix grep allows pickings keys based on matching regex.

    Sed filter can rename or delete key values keys just like unix sed by substitution (s) command or delete command (d).

    FLAG_INHERIT
    Indicates that the resource's properties should inherit from parent or default configurations.

    Specifies that the resource is locked and its properties should not be overridden.

    Indicates that the key-value pairs from the resource should only be added to variables and not to the final resolved key-value set.

      static final String FLAG_NO_EMPTY
      Indicates that the resource should not be empty. Typically used to enforce that the resource contains at least one key-value pair.
      See Also:
      • Constant Field Values

    • FLAG_LOCK

      static final String FLAG_LOCK
      Specifies that the resource is locked and its properties should not be overridden. This is distinct from FLAG_NO_REPLACE, which has different semantics.
      See Also:

      static final String KEY_MEDIA_TYPE

      static final String KEY_PARAM
      Represents the key for specifying parameters associated with a resource and are usually suffixed with a separator and name of the parameter.

      • Constant Field Values

    • KEY_FILTER

      static final String KEY_FILTER
      Key for specifying filters to apply to the resource. The name after the last DEFAULT_KEY_SEP is the filter id. The value of the key is the filter expression and its syntax and semantics vary by filter.
      See Also:
      • KeyValuesServiceProvider.KeyValuesFilter

    • SCHEMA_CLASSPATH

      static final String SCHEMA_CLASSPATH
      Classpath resource is loaded using KeyValuesEnvironment.getResourceStreamLoader(). 
      _load_app=classpath:///app.properties
      See Also:
      • Constant Field Values

    • SCHEMA_FILE

      static final String SCHEMA_FILE
      File resource which is the default if no schema is given. 
      _load_somefile=file:///./app.properties
_load_another=another.properties
      See Also:
      • Constant Field Values

    • SCHEMA_SYSTEM

      static final String SCHEMA_SYSTEM
      System properties which come from KeyValuesEnvironment.getSystemProperties().

      This schema can take a path that fetches a key value, where the value is used as the source of the key values. If no path is provided, all key values of the resource will be loaded.

      See Also:
      • Constant Field Values

    • SCHEMA_ENV

      static final String SCHEMA_ENV
      Environment variables which come from KeyValuesEnvironment.getSystemEnv().

      This schema can take a path that fetches a key value, where the value is used as the source of the key values. If no path is provided, all key values of the resource will be loaded.

      See Also:
      • Constant Field Values

    • SCHEMA_CMD

      static final String SCHEMA_CMD
      Command line argument pairs separated by =.

      This schema can take a path that fetches a key value, where the value is used as the source of the key values. If no path is provided, all key values of the resource will be loaded.

      See Also:
      • Constant Field Values

    • SCHEMA_STDIN

      static final String SCHEMA_STDIN
      Allows Unix piping of key values, often useful for passwords.

      stdin:/// without a path assumes that the entire contents of stdin are in java.util.Properties key-value format. If this is not the case, it is advisable to specify _mediaType= explicitly with stdin.

      stdin:/// can also bind the input content, parsed as a UTF-8 string, to the key provided in the URI path. 
      _load_stdin=stdin:///db.password?_flag=sensitive,optional
      Stdin is retrieved from KeyValuesEnvironment.getStandardInput().
      See Also:
      • Constant Field Values

    • SCHEMA_PROFILE

      static final String SCHEMA_PROFILE
      Will load multiple resources based on a CSV of profiles where the profile name replaces part of the URI.
      See Also:
      • Constant Field Values

    • FILTER_GREP

      static final String FILTER_GREP
      Grep filter just like unix grep allows pickings keys based on matching regex.
      See Also:
      • FILTER_GREP
      • Constant Field Values

    • FILTER_SED

      static final String FILTER_SED
      Sed filter can rename or delete key values keys just like unix sed by substitution (s) command or delete command (d).
      See Also:
      • FILTER_GREP
      • Constant Field Values

    • parameters

      Variables.Parameters parameters()
      Returns the parameters associated with the resource which are specified with the resource key "param". Parameters are away to configure custom plugins.
      Returns:
      the parameters as Variables.Parameters
      See Also:
      • KeyValuesServiceProvider

      String name()
      Returns the name of the resource.
      Returns:
      the name of the resource

    • reference

      @Nullable KeyValue reference()
      Returns the KeyValue that references this resource, if any. This is normally the load key in the parent resource loaded key values.
      Returns:
      the reference KeyValue, or null if not applicable

    • mediaType

      @Nullable String mediaType()
      Returns the media type of the resource, if specified.
      Returns:
      the media type, or null if not specified
